quartz glass reactor.The catalyst powder (0.1 g) was suspended in 200 mL of 1 M NaHCO 3 solution ( pH 8) under stirring.Before illumination, pure CO 2 was bubbled through the stirred solution to eliminate the air and to saturate the solution.After stopping the passage of CO 2 , the photoreaction was then carried out with a 300 W xenon arc lamp.Liquid products from the above system were detected on a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890B GC) connected with a headspace autosampler (Agilent 7697A HS).All samples

Two-dimensional MoS 2 nanosheets were in situ grown on TiO 2 nanosheets to form two-dimensional (2D) hybrid nanojunctions, with which MoS 2 nanosheets compactly contact with TiO 2 to increase the interfacial area.MoS 2 was identified as a promising cost-effective substitute for noble metal cocatalysts such as Pt, Au, and Ag, and shows superior activity and selectivity for reducing CO 2 to CH 3 OH in aqueous solution to these metal cocatalysts under UV-vis light irradiation.The photo-luminescence (PL)

(Agilent 7697A HS).All samples were treated at 300 C under an Ar atmosphere for 2 h for the removal of organic adsorbates before the photocatalysis reaction. For the preparation of 0.5 wt Pt, Au, and Ag loaded on TiO 2 nanosheets, the loading of Ag, Au, and Pt was performed by a photocatalytic reduction deposition method.H 2 PtCl 6 6H 2 O, HAuCl 4 4H 2 O, and AgNO 3 were used as the source of Pt, Au, and Ag.Typically, 0.2 g photocatalyst, 40 mL distilled water, 15 mL CH 3 OH and a given amount of source

evidence.pdf_reference: quartz glass reactor.The catalyst powder (0.1 g) was suspended in 200 mL of 1 M NaHCO 3 solution ( pH 8) under stirring.Before illumination, pure CO 2 was bubbled through the stirred solution to eliminate the air and to saturate the solution.After stopping the passage of CO 2 , the photoreaction was then carried out with a 300 W xenon arc lamp.Liquid products from the above system were detected on a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890B GC) connected with a headspace autosampler (Agilent 7697A HS).All samples

OH and a given amount of source were placed in a glass vessel.The reactant solution was irradiated by a 300 W Xe arc lamp for 8 h with stirring.Then, the photocatalyst with co-catalysts was filtered, washed thoroughly with deionized water and alcohol, and dried at 60 C for 12 h.All samples were treated at 300 C under an Ar atmosphere for 2 h.

measurements were performed at room temperature. The decay behavior of the samples can be well-fitted to a biexponential function in the form of f(t) A 1 exp(-t 1 ) A 2 exp(-t 2 ). The average lifetime is calculated by the expression in the form of (A 1 1 2 A 2 2 2 )(A 1 1 A 2 2 ).The apparent electrontransfer rate was able to be calculated using the equation in the form of k et 1(TiO 2 -MoS 2 ) -1(TiO 2 ). The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was carried out in an airtight quartz glass reactor.The

mainly selectively photoreduced to CH 3 OH without any noble-metal co-catalysts such as Pt and Au and oxides RuO 2 .Negligible small amounts of C 2 H 5 OH and CH 3 CHO were also detected.The CH 3 OH production rate of 0.5 wt MoS 2 TiO 2 (10.6 mol g -1 h -1 ) is about 2.9 times higher than that of pure TiO 2 (3.7 mol g -1 h -1 ), indicative of MoS 2 serving as an efficient cocatalyst.However, a further increase of the MoS 2 content (from 1 wt to 3 wt) leads to a gradual decrease of the photocatalytic

photo-luminescence (PL) spectra and transient time-resolved PL decay measurements reveal that the fast electron transfer from TiO 2 to MoS 2 can minimize charge recombination losses to improve the conversion efficiency of photoreduction.It reveals that Mo-terminated edges of MoS 2 nanosheets possess the metallic character and a high d-electron density, and the Mo cation sites may benefit the stabilization of CH x O y intermediates via electrostatic attraction to enhance the CH 3 OH formation from the
